intro: Gasteranthus caligula, commonly known as the "Coffin Flower," is a striking member of the Rubiaceae family native to the Andes. It is characterized by its unique, urn-shaped flowers that are typically violet or purple in color. The plant produces a fleshy, berry-like structure that encloses its seeds, a feature that aids in its pollination and seed dispersal. Gasteranthus caligula thrives in humid, shaded environments and requires well-drained soil. Its ornamental value has made it a sought-after plant in botanical gardens and among plant enthusiasts.
